title: FCA drops Libor probe into former Tom Hayes contemporary 'Pete the Greek'
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Tue, Aug 4, 2015, 21:06 BST - UK Markets closed FCA drops Libor probe into former Tom Hayes contemporary 'Pete the Greek' By Marion Dakers | Telegraph – 8 minutes ago -0.12 
Regulator fails to find evidence of dishonesty 
The financial regulator has dropped an investigation into a former senior UBS banker caught up in the Libor scandal, after its own review panel found there was not a strong enough case to pursue him. 
The Financial Conduct Authority will not take enforcement action against Panagiotis Koutsogiannis, known as 'Pete the Greek' to his colleagues, after the independent experts on its regulatory decision committee found that dishonest conduct was not proven. 
“After a long and detailed investigation and a full hearing of the Regulatory Decisions Committee of the FCA it was concluded that Mr Koutsogiannis’ conduct was neither dishonest nor lacking in integrity,” said Ben Rose, Mr Koutsogiannis’ lawyer and a founding partner of Hickman & Rose. 
The FCA, which declined to comment, has the power to fine and ban City workers from certain financial roles if they are found to have acted dishonestly. 
The blow to the regulator's efforts to investigate Libor, first reported by the Financial Times , comes a day after Tom Hayes, a former contemporary of Mr Koutsogiannis at UBS (NYSEArca: FBGX - news ) , was jailed for 14 years for conspiracy to defraud linked to attempted Libor-rigging. 
Hayes, the first person to be convicted by a jury in the global investigation into Libor, was told that his sentence was a "message sent to the world of banking" about the potential punishments that await dishonest financiers. 
During Hayes’ trial, the court was shown an email he sent to Mr Koutsogiannis, then the bank’s head of funding for the rates division, asking for approval to place a trade that could move Libor lower. 
“Hi mate, we have a big 1m fixing position over the next month,” Hayes wrote in July 2008. “My question is can I use some balance sheet in the market for 1m? We really need to get the fixing down.” 
The FCA’s regulatory decision committee reviews the findings of the watchdog on some contested matters. The panel is designed to be independent from the team at the centre of the issue, and hears cases where the person under investigation disputes the watchdog’s version of events. 
The 11-person committee, staffed with former auditors, police and financiers, last month prompted the closure of the investigation into Bruno Iksil , the JP Morgan trader known as the London Whale. 
Meanwhile, the Serious Fraud Office aims to bring more charges against traders linked to the manipulation of Libor later this year. "I have said further charges are likely ... in the autumn. Our Libor investigation is far-reaching and quite wide ... We haven’t finished yet," SFO director David Green told Reuters.
